document_metadata.description: Heme BEL model is a disease model based on Biological Expression Language (BEL) containing the core mechanisms of heme as modulator in Hemolytic diseases such as sickle-cell anemia, beta-thalassemia, malaria and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.
document_metadata.name: heme_29929138.bel

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: Nonfunctioning CD59 is a major risk factor for stroke and hypercoagulability.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: More recently, we have described two infants carrying the mutation who manifested with recurrent strokes [8], establishing the concept that primary Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59 leads to a thrombophilic state.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: We recently encountered patients with recurrent strokes leading to premature death in 2/7 young children with primary Cys89Tyr CD59 deficiency [8].

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: Nonfunctioning CD59 is a major risk factor for stroke and hypercoagulability.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: The Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59 was initially described with manifestation in infancy by chronic hemolysis and relapsing peripheral demyelinating disease resembling recurrent Guillain- Barre syndrome (GBS) or chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP).

citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: However, in primary Cys89Tyr CD59 deficiency and not in PNH, the endothelial cells are exposed to MACmediated injury.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: We have assessed the presence of MPs in four patients with primary Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59 and two PNH patients, as well as in four healthy donors.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: In summary, patients with primary Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59 showed about 9–10-fold increase in the number of MPs compared to controls and slightly but significantly increased numbers when com pared to PNH patients. The origin of MPs was primarily RBCs and to a much lesser extent platelets and neutrophils.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: The average mean fluorescence (MF) for CD61 staining of was slightly reduced in patients with primary Cys89Tyr CD59 deficiency and PNH as compared to controls. However, the average MF for CD62P expression in the healthy individuals was 38.3 ± 3.1 compared to 48.5 ± 4.7 in patients with primary Cys89Tyr CD59 deficiency (p < 0.0085) and 54.0 ± 4.2 in patients with PNH (p < 0.0013), indicating a significantly more activated platelet phenotype in both the patients with PNH and those with primary Cys89Tyr CD59 deficiency.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: It is thus plausible to suggest that the increased monocyte-platelet interaction in patients with primary Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59 is related to an activated platelet phenotype.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: Interaction between monocytes and platelets was suggested to be via p selection [17], which was shown here to be much higher in patients with primary Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: High free hemoglobin was shown in patients with primary Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59 (Table 1) and it has been suggested in several ways that free hemoglobin may serve as a major mechanism for thrombophilia.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: Although aggregation has not been investigated in PNH, we clearly show here that in primary Cys89Tyr CD59 mutation there is a significant increase in coaggregation with high numbers of activated platelets adhering to a single monocyte, and granulocytes to monocytes, that may lead to nonendothelial-bound arterial occlusion, among other effects [36].

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: CD59 deficiency is a common finding in adult patients with PNH, which is characterized by clonal expansion of hematopoietic stem cells that have acquired a mutation in the PIGA gene (phosphatidylinositol glycan anchor biosynthesis, class A).

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: PIGA encodes a GPI biosynthesis protein, phosphatidylinositol N-acetylglucosaminyltransferase subunit A [5, 6], and erythrocytes deficient in GPI-anchored membrane proteins, including CD59, undergo complement-mediated hemolysis.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: The endothelium normally expresses high levels of CD59, which protects endothelial cells in healthy individuals and in PNH patients from MAC-mediated injury.

citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: Interestingly, we have recently reported an association with venous thrombosis for lack of CD55 [45], so PNH patients lacking both CD55 and CD59 may suffer from both venous and arterial thrombosis.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: Endothelial injury may also be related to Free hemoglobin and its breakdown oxidative product heme, and MPs, which mediates direct proinflammatory, proliferative, and pro-oxidant effects on endothelial cells [22–24] both in PNH and congenital CD59 deficiency, but may be more pronounced in congenital CD59 deficiency and perhaps even more in the brain due to loss of CD59 in the endothelium of these patients.

links.evidence: In contrast to platelet lysis, platelet activation is clearly seen, based on both the higher expression of CD62P (Fig. 3B) and increased coaggregation with white blood cells.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: Surface accumulation of MAC may be at least partially responsible for the activated platelet phenotype seen in patients with primary Cys89Tyr CD59 mutation, as manifested both by increased CD62P expression and monocyte-platelet aggregates.

citation.name: Thrombosis research
citation.title: Prothrombotic mechanisms in patients with congenital p.Cys89Tyr mutation in CD59.

links.evidence: Although aggregation has not been investigated in PNH, we clearly show here that in primary Cys89Tyr CD59 mutation there is a significant increase in coaggregation with high numbers of activated platelets adhering to a single monocyte, and granulocytes to monocytes, that may lead to nonendothelial-bound arterial occlusion, among other effects [36].

links.evidence: Ziakas et al. [38] described 38 reports of arterial thrombosis, mainly in the central nervous system or coronary arteries in PNH patients.

links.evidence: Interestingly, we have recently reported an association with venous thrombosis for lack of CD55 [45], so PNH patients lacking both CD55 and CD59 may suffer from both venous and arterial thrombosis.
